author: Michael McNulty
title: Calling All Deadheads!
description: Catalyst sits at the forefront of innovation in distributed decision-making. We don't have any historical models to guide us. Or do we?

assessments.note: This proposal a focused example that doesn't misses the some aspects of the challenge. It doesn't include details on how it would grow beyond Deadheads. Even so, it hints at something bigger, a need for a repository of resources to study the history of decentralized decision making which is curated for the catalyst community.

Honestly, I don't know how to feel about this one.
It's intriguing and I'm curious as to what might come from it. So I'm going to go with a neutral score and see where it goes.
We might even get some cult onboard out of all this!
Interesting.

Not sure how can this assist the community's mission other than marketing the vision of Cardano. Perhaps more clarity on explaining the solution can strengthen the challenge. Governance is definitely one of the hardest projects to achieve in Cardano and any model that can bring inspiration should be onboarded and welcomed. Reading a book defining the key proposal topics is not a way to bring confidence in the proposal.

I mean, it's a different than usual proposal, that's for sure :D But, if there is a system of governance and information sharing that works and we can learn from it, then it definitely addresses the challenge.

The proposer seems to be a superfan. With 5k in his pocket he'll go through walls to meet his favorite band and will let nothing get in his way.
Dangerous, but I believe the community might have a base to go on this 'long, strange trip' with him and find out what lies at the end.

The experience is quite vast and passionate and his understanding on his vision of success is quite clear. Wouldn't make any judgement as to the success of the implemented approach without reading more about the structure of the topics involved in the proposed source of inspiration behind the topic of governance and decentralized approach examples of thereof.

As the proposer says himself, he is a big fan of Grateful Dead and that's his experience. Plan is not properly developed, but it is pretty simple: get in touch with people around the band, try to learn from them and try to teach them about Cardano and Project Catalyst.

The proposal lacks details on the goals and methods of the outreach, how many people should the example of Deadheads be shared with in order to be considered successful? How would the cardano community reach out to Deadheads? How would the sharing between communities be measured?

I would advice to add an outline or examples of the topics carried out on speaking engagements and outreach efforts. More clarity on the pragmatic aspect of the philosophy of the Deadman examples narrowed down and there relevance with the Cardano's governance goal and where it can benefit it specifically.

There is only a general plan of action in the proposal, I would love to see the names of people to contact, and more importantly, a cost breakdown of incentives for reaching out to the Deadhead community.

solution: Pre-Internet, the Grateful Dead created and maintained a distributed and decentralized, yet deeply committed community. What can we learn?
experience: I'm just a dude that really likes the Grateful Dead.
